clean_story:
Global internet highways. Hidden ocean habitats.

"Undersea cables" are fiber-optic wires laid on the ocean floor—carrying 99% of intercontinental data.


Most see them as silent data pipes. Few realize they’re artificial reefs.

A cable’s concrete armor and steel mesh create nooks for barnacles, mussels, and tube worms. Over years, these clusters attract crabs, lobsters, and fish—like a sunken skyscraper’s lobby.
One study off Spain found 1,500 species on a single retired cable. Octopuses nest in the gaps. Conger eels coil around the casing.

Yet this isn’t accidental. Engineers now design "reef-friendly" cables with textured surfaces to boost marine life—turning infrastructure into habitat.

Three related subjects are cable-laying ships, deep-sea mining impacts, and how whales use sound.
